pdhp195:1: Neither going naked, nor matted hair, nor mud, nor fasting or lying on stony ground,
pdhp195:2: dusty clothes, or striving while squatting, can purify a mortal who has not removed uncertainty.
pdhp196:1: Even if he were to adorn himself, but is trained, peaceful, settled, living by Dhamma,
pdhp196:2: and has put aside the stick towards all living beings, he is a brahmin, an ascetic, a monastic.
pdhp197:1: Do not speak anything harsh, spoken to they might answer back to you,
pdhp197:2: for arrogant talk entails misery, and they might strike you back with a stick.
pdhp198:1: If you make a sound like a gong that is struck,
pdhp198:2: you will undergo the rounds of births and deaths for a long time.
pdhp199:1: If you make no sound like a gong that is not struck,
pdhp199:2: you are like one who has attained Nibbāna, contention is not found in you.
pdhp200:1: Like a cowherd with a stick drives cattle to pasture,
pdhp200:2: so do old age and death overpower living beings.
pdhp201:1: Like a cowherd with a stick protects the owner’s cattle,
pdhp201:2: so one should watch over oneself, and you should not let the moment pass,
pdhp201:3: for when the chance has passed they grieve when consigned to the underworld.
pdhp202:1: Everyone trembles at sticks, for all of them life is dear,
pdhp202:2: comparing oneself with others, one should not hurt or have them hurt.
pdhp203:1: One who harms with a stick beings who desire happiness,
pdhp203:2: while seeking happiness for himself, won’t find happiness after death.
pdhp204:1: One who harms not with a stick beings who desire happiness,
pdhp204:2: while seeking happiness for himself, will find happiness after death.
pdhp205:1: One should not keep company with wicked friends, one should not keep company with the ignoble,
pdhp205:2: you should keep company with the sage and wise, you should keep company with superior people.
pdhp205:3: keeping company with such is surely better for you, not worse.
pdhp206:1: One should regard someone who shows your faults just like one who points out hidden treasure,
pdhp206:2: one should keep company with such a sagacious person who reproves you;
pdhp206:3: keeping company with such is surely better for you, not worse.
pdhp207:1: One should advise and instruct, and forbid whatever is vile,
pdhp207:2: for this is dear to the good, but it is not dear to the bad.
pdhp208:1: Therefore the good and the bad from here go to various destinies,
pdhp208:2: the bad go to the underworld, the good cross over to heaven.
pdhp209:1: The person of little learning increases in age like an ox,
pdhp209:2: for although his flesh does increase, his wisdom does not increase.
pdhp210:1: There are four states the man who is heedless, the man who consorts with other man’s wives, undergoes:
pdhp210:2: he gains demerit, an uncomfortable bed, blame as third, and rebirth in the underworld as fourth.
pdhp211:1: Gaining demerit and a bad destiny, and only the little delight of a scared man with a scared woman,
pdhp211:2: and kings who apply heavy punishment, at the break up of the body he goes to the underworld.
pdhp212:1: The restrained go to a good destiny, the unrestrained go to a bad destiny,
pdhp212:2: thinking: “I should not exhibit confidence,” the wise one wanders peacefully.
pdhp213:1: Do not, elephant, approach the Buddha, for there is suffering, elephant, in approaching the Buddha,
pdhp213:2: for the one who attacks the Buddha, elephant, does not go from here to a good destiny.
pdhp214:1: As a lion wanders his mountain fortress, his resort on the mountainside,
pdhp214:2: do not hurt the man-hero, the one without fear, the one of superior effort.
pdhp215:1: Like an elephant in battle endures arrows shot from bow
pdhp215:2: so will I endure abuse, for many people are unvirtuous.
